audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining his presence, mentioning a press release the following day regarding the first original Australian genome. He notes an upcoming science paper that explores what this genome reveals about early modern human dispersal. The speaker's tone is informative and academic.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing how recent information "actually changes our view on the early dispersal of modern man." He explains that the previous general notion was that there was one expansion eastwards, but now researchers can show that it probably did not happen that way. The speaker maintains a neutral tone throughout the clip.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing early human expansions, mentioning "at least two early expansions eastwards," and detailing how the ancestors of aboriginal Australians expanded into the world 70,000 years ago. He contrasts this with the ancestors of Europeans and Asians who were in Africa or the Middle East, "not really daring entering the world," while the Australians were "just crossing all the way to Australia." The speaker's tone is informative and conversational.
A male voice speaks in a relatively neutral tone, describing a timeline of human migration, mentioning "30,000 years later" and movements into "Europe" and "Asia."

The clip begins with a male speaker talking in a serious tone, explaining how the ancients met the remnants of the first expansion and mixed with them in some places in Asia, which explains why original Australians and Asians are genetically more similar to each other compared to the original Australians and Europeans. The speaker continues discussing the use of a hair sample collected by a British anthropologist in the early 1920s, and its Southwestern Australian origin. The idea of the sample was "to increase the chances of getting an unadmixed" genome. The speaker goes on to explain the possibility of obtaining genome sequences from museum collections, discussing the exploration of population genetics and history. The male speaker also highlights that there is "no evidence of recent European admixture", and that "all contamination from all the people" is on the surface of the hair, which can be removed.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing DNA extraction from various sources. He starts by mentioning, "Only the intact, indigenous DNA", then explains how "Bone and teeth are porous", leading to contamination from microbes and handling. In contrast, he describes hair as "like a plastic surface" with contaminants lying on the outside. The speaker says, "even though hair, you can say per gram of material contain much less DNA than bone and teeth", it's easier to get a cleaner result. His tone is informative and analytical.

The audio clip features a single male speaker, who describes how scientists, specifically "archeogeneticists" and "DNA specialists", isolate DNA away from other components and biological material. His tone is informative and somewhat technical. He mentions isolating the DNA from cellular components like fats and proteins found in hair shafts. There are no discernible background noises or music present in the clip.

The audio features a male speaker discussing a scientific process involving DNA isolation and sequencing, describing how it's smashed into pieces and then reassembled like a "billion-piece jigsaw" to create a comprehensive picture. He elaborates on using "new sequencing technology" to examine old samples. The overall tone is informative and slightly enthusiastic, conveying the excitement of the scientific endeavor.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing how people "move" and how their "DNA changes over time." He describes genetic changes as leaving "genetic breadcrumbs." His tone is conversational and informative. The audio contains no music or notable background sounds.

The clip features one male speaker describing how genetic code can be used to "look at these pieces of DNA" and understand changes, similarities, and differences to infer how populations behaved over time. He speaks in a clear, informative tone, discussing "intermingling" and population movement.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the long-known presence of Aboriginal people in Australia, mentioning archaeological evidence indicating their presence for "40,000, now 50,000 years." He explains that new evidence suggests an even longer history, noting past difficulties in extending the timeframe and some "controversial" sites dated to 60,000 years. He concludes that this new information indicates that people have been in the region or separated from other groups for "70,000 years perhaps," giving "a timeframe that's much older."

The audio presents a single male speaker discussing Australia's isolation and unique fauna, emphasizing the difficult sea crossing from Asia. He asserts that the people who reached Australia possessed foresight, planning, communication skills, and the ability to conceptualize, suggesting they were modern humans. He highlights the arrival in Australia as one of the earliest achievements of modern humans, and mentions the timeline of that arrival has been pushed back from 50,000 to 70,000 years.

A man is speaking in an informative tone, discussing archaeological work in southwestern Australia. He mentions his father's work starting in the 1970s at "Devil's there," a site with a long sequence of cave occupation. He describes being part of a team that re-dated the sediments in the 1990s using luminescence techniques.

The clip features a male speaker emphasizing that a site is very well-dated and a potential resource for looking at human occupation. The speaker transitions to mentioning the recovery of human DNA, working with traditional owners, and looking at how people arrived and where they came from. He also mentions plant and animal DNA in sediments as being potentially interesting. The clip then transitions to a different male speaker who explains that research began because of the cultural concerns of the Aboriginal people.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the cultural value of a hair sample beyond its scientific value. He mentions concerns about how the sample was collected and the research being done on it. He researched how the sample was collected, finding that Cambridge anthropologist Alfred Haddon collected it during a stop in a small town called Golden Ridge in 1923. At the time, Aboriginal people were trading artifacts for food and money along the trans line. He concludes by saying that someone gave up the hair sample in exchange for something from Haddon, and that's how it found its way to Cambridge University.

A male speaker is talking about the Goldfields Land and Sea Council and how they learned about some research and expressed concerns. Then, Professor Willis Lev came to Australia to discuss his research with the board, which was greatly appreciated. The board, representing the people of the region, gave their "unqualified endorsement." He then mentions that while there is a lot of interest in the results, not everyone accepts that the scientific discourse is the only explanation for people's origins, but there were no qualifications on having the research done.
